review.title: Joining Hands: Exploiting Monolingual Treebanks for Parsing of Code-mixing Data
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose efficient and less resource-intensive strategies for parsing of code-mixed data. These strategies are not constrained by in-domain annotations, rather they leverage pre-existing monolingual annotated resources for training. We show that these methods can produce significantly better results as compared to an informed baseline. Besides, we also present a data set of 450 Hindi and English code-mixed tweets of Hindi multilingual speakers for evaluation. The data set is manually annotated with Universal Dependencies.

These strategies are not constrained by domain annotations, but use existing monolingual annotated resources for training. We show that these methods can deliver significantly better results compared to an informed basis. We also present a dataset of 450 tweets from Hindi and English with mixed codemixed speakers for evaluation. The dataset is manually assigned universal dependencies.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The phenomenon is prevalent in spoken language and in the informal environment of social media, such as news groups, blogs, chat forums, etc. The most important factors are non-compliance with standard grammar, spelling variations and / or reverse transliteration. It has been generally observed that traditional NLP techniques pose a greater challenge than monolingual data in the processing of code mix data due to a variety of factors (Solorio and Liu, 2008b; Vyas et al., 2014; C-etinog, lu et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 2 Parsing Strategies
sections.text: These strategies differ in the way they use existing treebanks to parse code-mixed data. • Monolingual: However, the monolingual method is disconnected from the respective monolingual method, which is based on the respective monolingual treebanks of the languages present in the code-mixed data. We can use the monolingual parser models in two different ways. First, we can analyze each code-mixed sentence by intelligently selecting the monolingual model based on the matrix language of the sentence. 2 A clear disadvantage of this method is that the monolingual parser cannot precisely parse these language models, the fragments of a sentence belonging to a language unknown to the model. Therefore, we consider this to be the basic method. Secondly, we can equalize the predictions of both monolingual models at the intersection time.

sections.heading: 3 Code-mixed Dependency Annotations
sections.text: To the best of our knowledge, there is no available code-mixed dataset that contains dependency annotations, but there are some available code-mixed datasets that contain annotations on the language of a token, its POS, and chunk tags. To intrinsically evaluate our analytical models on code-mixed texts, we manually commented on a dataset of code-mixed tweets with dependency structures. Code-mixed tweets were evaluated from a large number of tweets from Indian users that we crawled with Tweepy3-a Twitter API wrappers from Twitter. We used a language identification system (see § 4) to filter Hindi-English code-mixed tweets from the crawled Twitter data. Only3http: / www.tweepy.org / these tweets were selected that met a minimum ratio of 30: 70 (%) code mixes.

sections.heading: 4 Preprocessing
sections.text: The parsing strategies we discussed above for code-mixed texts rely heavily on the language identification of individual tokens, and we also need the normalization of non-standard word forms that predominate in code mix social media content and back transcriptions of Romanized Hindi words. Here, we discuss both preprocessing steps in short form. We model language identification as a classification problem in which each token must be placed in one of the following categories: "Hindi," "acronym" (s), "Named Entity" (ne), and "Universal" (univ). For this task, we use the feedforward neural network architecture of Bhat et al. (2016) 4 proposed words in code-mixed-data-mixed-data-data-data-data of Indian languages. We train the network with similar feature representations on the task shared in ICON 20155.

sections.heading: 6 Experiments and Results
sections.text: We conducted several experiments to measure the effectiveness of the proposed parsing strategies both in gold and in predicted settings. In predicted settings, we used the monolingual POS marker for all experiments. We used the monolingual method as a starting point for evaluating other parsing strategies. The baseline model analyzes each sentence in the assessment sentences using either Hindi or English parsing model based on the matrix language of the sentence. For the baseline and multipass methods, we use bilingual embedding space derived from the matrix language to represent lexical nodes in the input layer of our parsing architecture. In the interpolation method, we use separate monolingual embedding spaces for each model. The interpolation weights are matched using the development set and the best results are obtained on the basis.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we evaluated various strategies for parsing code-mixed data that use only monolingual annotated data. We have shown that code-mixed texts can be efficiently analyzed by the monolingual parsing models if intelligently manipulated. As opposed to an informed monolingual baseline, our parsing strategies are at least 10 LAS points better. Among the different strategies we have proposed, multilingual and interpolation methods are two competitive methods for parsing code-mixed data. The code of the parsing models is available in the GitHub repository https: / / github. com / irshadbhat / cm-parser, while the data can be found in the Universal Dependencies of Hindi at https: / / github.com / Universal Dependencies / UD _ Hindi.
